Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Ligand-induced Folding in Peptides for Biosensing Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project, funded by the Chemical Measurement and Imaging program of the Division of Chemistry and the EPSCoR office, Professor Lai from University of Nebraska at Lincoln proposes to develop a potentially generalizable peptide-based electrochemical biosensing platform for detection of clinically relevant proteins. Professor Lai's work will address the question of how ligand-induced folding in peptides can be utilized in the design of folding-based electrochemical biosensors. A proof-of-concept study will focus on the detection of anti-HIV antibodies using peptide epitopes from HIV-related antigens. The sensor constructs to be investigated include both stem-loop and linear designs. In both sensor constructs, the distal end of the peptide is attached to an electrochemically active reporter, whereas the proximal end is selectively immobilized to an electrode surface. The analyte-induced change in the location of electrochemically active reporter will then determine the current observed in the system.

The proposed study has the potential to impact the field of biosensor development and facilitate the use of peptides as recognition components in a wide range of chemical and biological applications. Integrating concepts of electrochemistry and molecular biology, the project will provide training opportunities to undergraduate and graduate students. To support this training, an undergraduate course in general electrochemistry and a graduate course in advanced biosensing techniques will be developed. Professor Lai will also host an annual summer workshop on biosensor technology for Nebraska high school teachers, with the goal of preparing them with the knowledge of easy-to-demonstrate experiments for high school classes to spur students' interests in chemistry and biosensor technology.

Intellectual Merit:

The project focus was on developing a new electrochemical peptide-based (E-PB) biosensing platform for reagentless, real time detection of protein targets such as HIV antibodies. We evaluated the effect of peptide probe length, alkanethiol chain length, and redox label location on the overall sensor performance. Our results showed that short hydrophilic peptides with a 6-carbon alkanethiol linker were better suited for this sensing platform. We also analyzed the effect of incorporating extra hydrophilic and/or charged amino acids into the peptide recognition sequence to prevent non-specific binding and adsorption of matrix contaminants to the sensor surface. Our results showed that the incorporation of these amino acids to the peptide recognition sequence can improve the overall sensor specificity and selectivity. We further characterized E-PB sensors fabricated with an antifouling diluent such as thiolated oligothymine and mannose-terminated alkanethiol. These sensors were selective enough to be employed directly in complex biological samples such as saliva and serum. We also developed a hybrid technique, electrochemical-surface plasmon resonance spectroscopy, to characterize E-PB sensors. This technique enabled simultaneous optoelectrochemical analysis and was capable of differentiating between signals originating from specific target binding and non-specific adsorption. This versatile technique can potentially be used to characterize other electrochemical biosensors.

Broader Impact:

Our effort has also involved the training and development of 5 undergraduate students, 7 graduate students, 1 postdoctoral researcher, and 1 visiting professor. These include 7 female and 1 from underrepresented minority background. Most of them were co-authors on several research papers; three of the five undergraduate students published first author papers. Additionally, graduate students enrolled in a new Biosensor course were exposed to emerging science at the intersection of chemistry, biology, and nanotechnology. Many of the participants were involved in developing education and outreach activities related to this program. More than 10 outreach and education activities were dedicated to training K12 students, including a signature 7-week “Harry Potter x Science” after school program for elementary school students. An undergraduate Chemistry course entitled “A Muggle’s Guide to Harry Potter’s Chemistry” was also developed to introduce UNL undergraduate students to the science behind the Harry Potter book series. Additional activities that targeted the broader community such as the Sci-Pop talk series and Sunday with a Scientist events were also developed to augment the overall societal impact of this Career project.
